title: Oregon State defense has something to build on
text:
Activate your digital access. Oregon State defense has something to build on OSU nose tackle Kyke Peko talks about playing in his first homecoming game on Oct. 20, 2015. Gary Horowitz/Statesman Journal Gary Horowitz Statesman Journal 9:57 a.m. PDT October 21, 2015 Washington State running back Gerard Wicks (23) is brought down by Oregon State linebacker Caleb Saulo (35) during the first half of last Saturday’s game at Martin Stadium in Pullman. (Photo: James Snook-USA TODAY Sports) 3 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
CORVALLIS – It might sound peculiar, but the Oregon State football team's defensive has something to build on after last Saturday's 52-31 loss at Washington State. 
Sure, Luke Falk tossed six touchdown passes, but they all came in the first half when the Cougars accumulated 399 of their 510 total yards. 
In the second half, OSU's defense pitched a shutout and recorded two interceptions. Washington State's lone score came on a pick-six. 
It could be argued that the game was essentially over at the break, but if you look at the last 30 minutes of work from OSU's defense, there's a positive heading into Saturday's homecoming matchup against Colorado, which has lost 14 consecutive Pac-12 games. 
"All I see is the improvement we made in the second half," senior nose tackle Kyle Peko said. "I'm very hopeful that it will carry over into this game." Larry Scott questionable for Colorado game 
Why the optimism? Well, it sure beats doom and gloom. 
It's true, the Beavers (2-4, 0-3 Pac-12) have struggled to grasp the nuances of defensive coordinator Kalani Sitake's 3-4 base defense, and they haven't been very effective in the 4-3, either, at least not in conference games. 
More pressure on the quarterback would help. The eight sacks ranks last in the Pac-12. 
Injuries also have been an issue. Senior defensive end Jalen Grimble (knee) missed the past two games, and senior cornerback Larry Scott, the most experienced player in the secondary, is doubtful for Saturday's game with an ankle injury. 
But in the big picture, it comes down to execution according to junior strong safety Devin Chappell. 
"Like coach (Gary) Andersen says, we have to respect the process," Chappell said. "But at the end of the day there's no excuses. Our coaches are doing a great job teaching us the scheme. We have to do what they ask of us." 
The defensive numbers, as you would expect, are not good. OSU ranks 11th in the Pac-12 in scoring defense (33.5 points per game), 10th in rushing defense (198.5 yards per game) and eighth in total defense (414.7 ypg). 
Sitake, when asked to grade OSU's defensive performance at midseason, pointed to the bottom line rather than provide a letter grade. No quick fix for Beavers 
"Well, we're 2-4 (overall) and 0-3 in the league, so that's not really good," Sitake said, adding "what do you grade on when guys haven't even scored on the (goal sheet)? It's like handing in a blank piece of paper for the test." 
But Sitake, who was Utah's defensive coordinator last season when the Utes led the nation in sacks, was encouraged by the second half at WSU. 
He noted that "it just felt cleaner." 
"We just need to do that the whole game," Sitake said. "What's promising is they did that for a half and they learned it and saw it on film. If you watched the film with us the first half was ugly and the second half was like, Ok, it's working." 
Will the defensive continue to work as a cohesive unit against Colorado (3-4, 0-3)? If the answer is yes, OSU likely will be celebrating its first conference victory.
